description.text: I oversaw all aspects of planning, design, permitting and construction of a 50,000 SF expansion to NL Mercy Hospital in Portland, ME.  The expansion included a new Emergency Department, Intensive Care unit and other acute hospital departments. experience.title: Institute Chief Operating Officer
experience.company: Sisters of Mercy of the Americas
experience.location: Cumberland, Rhode Island, United States · Hybrid

description.text:
• Facilitated a major strategic repositioning process in full alignment with Shriners Hospital for Children (SHC) system direction, with planned outcomes to increase volume, improve efficiency, decrease overhead, and increase fundraising; formal strategic plan approved by the Board for 2020-2025.
• During the COVID pandemic, provided leadership for the Incident Command Center to manage total response; with MGH and DPH formal agreement, accepted adult burn patients after facility and staff preparation.
• Led and implemented Diversity, Equity, Inclusion response and strategies.
• Completed new agreements with Massachusetts General Hospital resulting in provider agreements required for billing; enhanced revenue cycle cash collections by $4M annually.
• Reduced operating expenses by $2M by redesigning in-patient care staffing.
• Exceeded fund raising goal each year of approximately $8M; restructured donor development processes for greater effectiveness; created virtual Halloween Walk during COVID with over $200K raised.
• Implemented a sophisticated outreach structure in collaboration with SHC Springfield, with business planning and provider liaison functions covering the Northeast Region.
• Completed facility transition plan to the level of schematic/detailed design for DPH plan review with 18 month construction time frame.
• Completed successful The Joint Commission (TJC) Survey in 2019.

• Led and directed the strategic planning and operations of Mercy Hospital; a not-for-profit Catholic health care organization comprised of 100 occupied (230 licensed) beds, 1300 FTEs including 150 FTE employed providers, and twelve care locations; net revenue of $200M.
• Skillfully initiated, managed, and monitored  Mercy Health System of Maine ownership transfer to Eastern Maine Healthcare Systems to create an accountable care infrastructure and facilitate access to capital.  
• Executed a definitive agreement to integrate Mercy Health System of Maine, including VNA Home Health and Hospice, into Eastern Maine Healthcare Systems, with closing of the transaction taking place following state approval and issuance of Certificate of Need.  Facilitated implementation of shared services models in finance, human resources, information technology, supply chain, and quality. 
• Completed building construction and opening of Phase I of Mercy Fore River, an $85 million total hospital replacement project, having obtained a Certificate of Need; provided leadership for the $15M Fore River Project capital campaign exceeding goal by $1M; obtained commitment for lead gift of $6M in second capital campaign.
• As President and CEO, grew net revenue from $100M to $230M over the course of eight years.
• Developed a cardiology model with a major competitor under Federal Trade Commission and state Attorney General supervision, recruited numerous specialty practices into an effective employment model, implemented an integrated hospitalist/physician extender service, and completed a primary care network plan with 45 providers in satellite practices throughout the Mercy primary service area.
• Initiated bundled pricing, and an efficient and streamlined process for comparative data analysis for the Mercy Orthopaedic Institute. Developed a highly successful orthopaedic co-management model comprised of independent community-based orthopaedic practices organized in an LLC structure.

experience.title: Executive Vice-President and Hospital Chief Executive Officer

description.text:
• Led and directed the strategic planning and operations of Ochsner Foundation Hospital (a teaching hospital and Division of Alton Ochsner Medical Foundation) and Ochsner Home Health, with a $350M operating budget, 2600 FTEs, and a closed medical staff.

• Supervised seven vice-presidents; reported to the Foundation physician CEO.  

• Served as Board Member, Ochsner Health Plan, Ochsner Home Health, and Brent House Hotel.

• Led the planning, completion, and opening of a $50M Critical Care Tower, including ED fast track.

• Collaborated with Ochsner Clinic to develop and complete a new Breast Center, Ambulatory Surgery Center, Pediatrics Center, and Center for Geriatric Medicine; obtained $3.5M donor support for the Breast Center.

fixedListComponent.text: Dr. Manish Vig and I have known each other for over five years and worked alongside each other as the Medical Director/Chief and Nursing Manager of a busy urban Emergency Department in Massachusetts. The clinical department had undergone significant change and turnover prior to my arrival, and it was critical for the two of us to continue building relationships with our respective teams and get buy in to a coherent vision to achieve excellent outcomes and care. We set out to work on a number of goals simultaneously that were not only important to our department but the hospital and community as well. These included streamlining clinical processes, onboarding of new providers, team-building, creating and implementing computerized order sets, minimizing disruptive behavior and creating a safe patient environment. I enjoyed working with Manish on these varied and challenging goals, and found him to be diligent and adept at navigating the department in a difficult environment. He was not only a strong patient advocate, but supported nursing initiatives whenever appropriate.   Kelly Chevalier, BSN, RN, CEN

publications.title: Emergency department visits among patients with left ventricular assist devices
publications.subtitle: Internal and Emergency Medicine · Dec 22, 2017

description.text: Continuous-flow left ventricular assist devices (LVADs) are increasingly implanted to support patients with end-stage heart failure. These patients are at high risk for complications, many of which necessitate emergency care. While rehospitalization rates have been described, there is little data regarding emergency department (ED) visits. We hypothesize that ED visits are frequent and often require admission after LVAD implantation. We performed a retrospective review of patients in our health-care system followed by the advanced heart failure service for LVAD management after implantation between January 2011 and July 2015. We accounted for all ED visits in our system through February 2016, 7 months after the last implantation included. Clinically relevant demographic variables and ED visit details were recorded and analyzed to describe this population. We identified 81 patients with complete data, among whom there were 283 visits (3.49 visits/patient), occurring at a rate of approximately 7.3 ED visits per patient per year alive with LVAD. The most common reason for an ED visit is a complication related to bleeding (18% of visits), followed by chest pain (14%) and dizziness or syncope (13%). Thirty-six percent of patients were discharged from the ED without hospital admission. A growing populace with implanted LVADs represents an important population within emergency medicine. They are at risk for significant complications and frequently present to the ED. While many of these visits may be managed without hospital admission, this specialized patient group represents a potential area for improvement in provider education.

publications.title: A new ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction equivalent pattern? Prominent T wave and J-point depression in the precordial leads associated with ST-segment elevation in lead aVr.
publications.subtitle: American Journal of Emergency Medicine · Mar 1, 2014

description.text:
Abstract
Certain acute coronary syndrome electrocardiographic (ECG) patterns, which do not include ST-segment elevation, are indicative of acute coronary syndrome caused by significant arterial occlusion; these patterns are, of course, associated with significant risk to the patient and mandate a rapid response from the health care team. One such high-risk ECG pattern includes the association of the prominent T wave and J-point depression producing ST-segment depression seen in the precordial leads coupled with ST-segment elevation in lead aVr. This ECG presentation is associated with significant left anterior descending artery obstruction. We report the case of a patient with this ECG presentation who progressed over a very short time to ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction of the anterior wall.

experience.title: Institute Chief Operating Officer
experience.company: Sisters of Mercy of the Americas
experience.location: Cumberland, Rhode Island, United States · Hybrid

description.text:
• Facilitated a major strategic repositioning process in full alignment with Shriners Hospital for Children (SHC) system direction, with planned outcomes to increase volume, improve efficiency, decrease overhead, and increase fundraising; formal strategic plan approved by the Board for 2020-2025.
• During the COVID pandemic, provided leadership for the Incident Command Center to manage total response; with MGH and DPH formal agreement, accepted adult burn patients after facility and staff preparation.
• Led and implemented Diversity, Equity, Inclusion response and strategies.
• Completed new agreements with Massachusetts General Hospital resulting in provider agreements required for billing; enhanced revenue cycle cash collections by $4M annually.
• Reduced operating expenses by $2M by redesigning in-patient care staffing.
• Exceeded fund raising goal each year of approximately $8M; restructured donor development processes for greater effectiveness; created virtual Halloween Walk during COVID with over $200K raised.
• Implemented a sophisticated outreach structure in collaboration with SHC Springfield, with business planning and provider liaison functions covering the Northeast Region.
• Completed facility transition plan to the level of schematic/detailed design for DPH plan review with 18 month construction time frame.
• Completed successful The Joint Commission (TJC) Survey in 2019.

• Led and directed the strategic planning and operations of Mercy Hospital; a not-for-profit Catholic health care organization comprised of 100 occupied (230 licensed) beds, 1300 FTEs including 150 FTE employed providers, and twelve care locations; net revenue of $200M.
• Skillfully initiated, managed, and monitored  Mercy Health System of Maine ownership transfer to Eastern Maine Healthcare Systems to create an accountable care infrastructure and facilitate access to capital.  
• Executed a definitive agreement to integrate Mercy Health System of Maine, including VNA Home Health and Hospice, into Eastern Maine Healthcare Systems, with closing of the transaction taking place following state approval and issuance of Certificate of Need.  Facilitated implementation of shared services models in finance, human resources, information technology, supply chain, and quality. 
• Completed building construction and opening of Phase I of Mercy Fore River, an $85 million total hospital replacement project, having obtained a Certificate of Need; provided leadership for the $15M Fore River Project capital campaign exceeding goal by $1M; obtained commitment for lead gift of $6M in second capital campaign.
• As President and CEO, grew net revenue from $100M to $230M over the course of eight years.
• Developed a cardiology model with a major competitor under Federal Trade Commission and state Attorney General supervision, recruited numerous specialty practices into an effective employment model, implemented an integrated hospitalist/physician extender service, and completed a primary care network plan with 45 providers in satellite practices throughout the Mercy primary service area.
• Initiated bundled pricing, and an efficient and streamlined process for comparative data analysis for the Mercy Orthopaedic Institute. Developed a highly successful orthopaedic co-management model comprised of independent community-based orthopaedic practices organized in an LLC structure.

• Supervised seven vice-presidents; reported to the Foundation physician CEO.  

• Served as Board Member, Ochsner Health Plan, Ochsner Home Health, and Brent House Hotel.

publications.title: Emergency department visits among patients with left ventricular assist devices
publications.subtitle: Internal and Emergency Medicine · Dec 22, 2017

description.text: Continuous-flow left ventricular assist devices (LVADs) are increasingly implanted to support patients with end-stage heart failure. These patients are at high risk for complications, many of which necessitate emergency care. While rehospitalization rates have been described, there is little data regarding emergency department (ED) visits. We hypothesize that ED visits are frequent and often require admission after LVAD implantation. We performed a retrospective review of patients in our health-care system followed by the advanced heart failure service for LVAD management after implantation between January 2011 and July 2015. We accounted for all ED visits in our system through February 2016, 7 months after the last implantation included. Clinically relevant demographic variables and ED visit details were recorded and analyzed to describe this population. We identified 81 patients with complete data, among whom there were 283 visits (3.49 visits/patient), occurring at a rate of approximately 7.3 ED visits per patient per year alive with LVAD. The most common reason for an ED visit is a complication related to bleeding (18% of visits), followed by chest pain (14%) and dizziness or syncope (13%). Thirty-six percent of patients were discharged from the ED without hospital admission. A growing populace with implanted LVADs represents an important population within emergency medicine. They are at risk for significant complications and frequently present to the ED. While many of these visits may be managed without hospital admission, this specialized patient group represents a potential area for improvement in provider education.

publications.title: A new ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction equivalent pattern? Prominent T wave and J-point depression in the precordial leads associated with ST-segment elevation in lead aVr.
publications.subtitle: American Journal of Emergency Medicine · Mar 1, 2014

description.text:
Abstract
Certain acute coronary syndrome electrocardiographic (ECG) patterns, which do not include ST-segment elevation, are indicative of acute coronary syndrome caused by significant arterial occlusion; these patterns are, of course, associated with significant risk to the patient and mandate a rapid response from the health care team. One such high-risk ECG pattern includes the association of the prominent T wave and J-point depression producing ST-segment depression seen in the precordial leads coupled with ST-segment elevation in lead aVr. This ECG presentation is associated with significant left anterior descending artery obstruction. We report the case of a patient with this ECG presentation who progressed over a very short time to ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction of the anterior wall.
